and the problem they had was quite common to organizations of their size
that had grown as quickly as they had uh now they had their fair share of what we
now call monolithic software but back then was just called software now there's nothing inherently
bad with monolitic software but these monoliths were the bad kind the the kind
that were tied and coupled in really scary ways to every critical system in the company um via black holes and

making changes everybody was quite rightly nervous about making

environment and then test The Living Daylights out of it and then release

and the rate of change was slow and this this was the the problem it was a really

fangled thing called microservices and microservices can be really good because they uh help take
your code and break it into small manageable chunks that can be deployed independently um understood more easily
removed um and this works pretty well
for them they they took uh a bit of new functionality instead of just shoehorning it into an existing monolith

more and a few more and then they discovered they had a
new problem uh they solved a problem by
using microservices but that had actually introduced a new problem and this is going to be a bit of a common
theme in my talk we solve problems and that leads us to discover new
problems now the new problem was the testing now it turns out when you
take uh when you when you decouple all your uh business code into nice little
bite-sized micros then you take an endtoend suite and put that over to test all your
microservices you actually recoupling your code at the test layer you're
undoing all that good decoupling work that you did in your business code and recoupling it in your test code um so
what this team at Rea discovered was that um making changes was becoming
slower again um one service would block the other service from being deployed
and it was undoing one of the goals of microservices which is to allow you to deploy um in Services
independently so this led them to really question the value they were getting out
of their testing should they should they do these tests or should they not um if
they if they didn't do them they risked letting integration bugs into production
and I mean that's the point of testing is that we we want to find our bugs before they go into production not

this solution I'm just going to do a little bit of a detour story so um a few months before I
started Consulting out at Rea I saw this really interesting talk by a guy called JB rainsburg you probably heard of him
um now this talk uh was discussing how to
test integration points and the title of it was integration tests or a scan and
he discussed an alternative approach to our traditional integration testing um
techniques that works like this imagine we had uh a consumer and a
provider now it doesn't really matter what the consumer provider are this this Theory Works whether it we're talking
about classes or modules or services it's all the same now we write a test for the
consumer to make sure that the uh consumer sends the right request to the
provider and we use a mock provider instead of the real provider and we
check that the right request is sent and that we can correctly handle the response that we get back now this is
nothing novel or exciting this is what we do all the time but if you have a look at this diagram you'll see that half of it is
missing what we're missing is the part where we send the same request to the provider
to make sure the provider actually does handle that request and looking at the
response that comes back to make sure that it actually does send the response that we think it will if we had these two matching sets
of tests we've achieved test symmetry we've effectively made sure
that our mock provider behaves the same way as our real provider does and this means that when these two components
meet each other in real life they're most likely going to work together correctly now I found this this concept
of this test symmetry really interesting um in this talk that JB was giving but I
um I found myself a little bit disappointed at the end of the talk because he didn't have any suggestions
for any tools that would help us achieve this test symmetry um so I finding this talk so
interesting I gave a brown bag on it to my consulting company and at the end of
it I said hey has anybody here heard of any tools that would help us achieve this test Symmetry and my workmate uh
Ron hen who was Consulting out at Rea at that time said well actually we've just
built a tool that does something really similar to that um and it's it's for
HTTP microservices and this is how it
worked H sorry let me let me tell you about testet first first we get the
reason this test symmetry solves problems is that we get this fast feedback on both sides we have these few
dependencies um when when you can run when you're running contract tests you don't need to have the world running you
just have the bit that you're interested in um you don't need a dedicated test
environment to run these tests in you can just run them in your normal noral CI on your local test environment and
use the same debugging tools that you would to do your normal coding would you
rather debug an issue on your local machine or would you really rather debug an issue uh on a test

deployment issues that complicate things um but we have introduced a new problem
it's now hard to keep those two sets of tests in sync now let me come back to this tool
that my workmate Ron was talking about now it was called packed and they
had uh developed this tool inhouse to help solve the problems that they were having with their distributed testing
environments and this is how it worked this diagram is going to look uh quite similar uh quite familiar to you
sorry um we have a consumer and we make a request to our mock provider
and this is a bit where it that pattern differs from what I was just discussing before while we're running those
tests we write the request and the expected response to a contract
file then we take that contract file over to the provider and we replay the request and
we look at the response that comes back and we make sure the response that comes back matches the expected response
and if it does we verified that our mock provider behaves the same way as our um
real provider now the thing that helps us here is we now have something to keep
these two sets of tests in sync our test symmetry solved the
problem of um of separating uh integration test and
this contract solves the problem of keeping those two sets in sync
now me uh not not all services are HTTP Services um a lot of services these days
are message Based Services and with message Services we actually have the same problem it's really easy for these
two sides to get out of sync and um in fact if something is uh unexpected or
mismatched between the consumer and provider sometimes it's even harder to find this issue because when something
goes wrong with an hdtp request you often get an immediate failure but with a message service the message might just
get dropped and accused somewhere uh you don't always get that immediate failure so having a contract between a consumer
provider is almost more important now you can do exactly the same thing uh
with a message contract you can write a test that shows that uh a consumer
handles an expected message a certain way and then you can write that message
to a contract and then you can run a test on the other side to make sure that the provider
actually does produce the message that you think it does so contract testing solves the
problem of keeping these two uh sides of our tests in sync and instead of uh
introducing a hpe of new problems it actually brings a lot of benefits now before I talk about those
benefits I just want to do a little bit of a uh a crowd survey here imagine
you've written um a piece of new code how long is it uh before you find out

hours more than a few weeks keep your hand up if you work at a bank

the bank anyway um wouldn't it be much better to find these bugs before we even
got to the deployment stage before we got to the to the um uh integration test
phase before we'd even pushed our code contract tests help you find find the
bug early in your um de velopment cycle so you're reducing the number of
integration bugs that you're even committing into your code
base now contracts help you make changes with um speed and confidence because you
get this really fast feedback and you can see what the impact of any change to an API will be really
fast contract test allow you to deploy independently because once your side of
the contract is working on both sides of the contra contract is working each of you can deploy at your own schedule so
the deployment schedule of your service is not slowed down by uh the slow
deployment cycle of another service now if you're using this type of
contract tring which is actually called consumer-driven contracts you're actually getting um you're actually
getting an even better design for your API now most apis are designed like this
I have a data source what's the fastest way I can get the data out of my data source into an HTTP
response that doesn't make for a really usable API because it's not thinking about how the consumer is actually going
to use this data so consumer-driven contracts actually turns that process around and starts by thinking well as
the consumer what way of formatting and and accessing this data makes sense for
me so you end up with an API that's actually um optimized for real world
usage because it's being driven by your real world
examples now I've told you a bit about what contract tests can do for you but
let me tell you a bit about what they don't do now contract tests are not
functional tests um one of the traps that developers often fall into when they start this type of testing is they
try and use the contract test to make sure that the provider has been implemented
correctly that's not the job of the contract test the contract test is there to make sure that the consumer and the
provider have a shared understanding of the messages that are going to flow between the system so here's a quick
example of the difference between a contract test and the functional test imagine I have an API where I am uh
sending a post to a collection to add a new object a contractor says hey when I
send you this payload I expect this kind of response and this this payload back
it doesn't say hey did you actually add this item to your data store the functional test says Hey when this
payload comes in do I actually add this object to my data store um that's not actually the concern
of the the consumer the consumer is concerned with what the requests and the responses look like it's the provide the
the job of the provider tests to make sure it does the right thing with what you're sending
now contract tests are not an API specification um so an API specification
describes what a service will do for everybody whereas a contract um is a
specific thing between an A consu and one consumer one provider and this is
what helps you make those changes quickly because you know exactly what each consumer expects from each provider
and whether the bit of code you're wanting to change is actually used by anyone
now it takes two to tango uh when you're writing a contract test it takes one side to uh record that
contract and the other side to replay and verify it so contract test or this
kind of contract test anyway doesn't really scale for public services and
services when there's just lots and lots of consumers um imagine if GitHub was
trying to um verify contracts with all of its millions of users it it just
doesn't work um that's when the traditional versioning approaches um of
never changeing API just Mak a new version um are a better
technique um consumer-driven contracts have this sweet spot for internal apis
where the number of consumers and provider teams are actually kind of small enough that you can maintain some
kind of personal relationship with each other now contract tests are not a
Silver Bullet they're not going to magically make every single integration testing problem you have go away but I'm
really confident that they will reduce them and and this is why now you you're probably aware of the
uh contract testing uh sorry the testing pyramid um and it's an overly simplistic
view of testing but um the main point that it expresses is really true and
this is that the more code that your test covers the fewer tests you should
of that type so endtoend tests are really good for making sure that the business value
of your code is being delivered and that everything is working together correctly but they're really bad at showing you
where something has gone wrong when it goes wrong isolated tests are are really good
at showing you where something has gone wrong um but they don't give you that confidence that everything is going to
work together now all of these types of tests have a role to play and the key is to get them in the right balance and
using the right test for the the right tool for the right job now problems arise when we try and
use end to-end tests for things that isolated or or smaller scoped
integration tests would do better when we try and use endtoend test to make sure that every field in our
request and our response is correct we end up in the testing pyramid of
hell that is testing harder not
smarter contract tests live on this boundary between um integrated tests and
isolated tests and they allow you to reduce the number of endtoend tests that you need because you're not using these
high level tests to check really low-level concerns that's already been
done this means you can really speed up up your release
cycle now this is not going to work for everybody but at the team that I ended
up joining at um Raa when I when I actually joined them um they actually
threw away all their end to-end tests and just relied on these contract tests
and in spend of instead of spending that time and effort on maintaining those end to-end tests they spent time and effort
on uh doing the things that would help them find and fix bugs quickly so these
were obviously the contract testing uh getting really good aggregated logging
uh really good metrics um semantic logging alerting um correlation ideas to
help them to see uh the flows of data through their systems and this meant that the turnaround time when issues
were discovered was really short they could find a bug and fix it in less than an hour so that meant that each
deployment um was muchow lower risk because they knew that everything went wrong it was really quick to recover
from now I'd like to tell you a bit more about um my experiences on that team
because that's what got me started in this whole contract testing Journey now when I started at Raa um
pack was just this little library that uh was running on this one team uh
written in Ruby for Ruby microservices and now it's grown to be an open source project uh for multiple language
covering multiple Proto multiple
protocols um I'd like to tell you a bit more about how that Library went from
being this little Ruby project to being this rather large open source project and and tell you about the problems that
we encountered and uh how we fix those problems because I might have told you a little white lie before when I said that
contract testing doesn't introduce new problems um it actually does but they're more interesting problems to solve than
integration testing all right so let me just do a
quick recap of how this works uh the consumer runs tests that check that the
consumer code is making the right calls uh by using a mock provider and we
record that conversation and then we replay it on the provider side um and we
make sure that the responses that we get back match the expected responses and if they do we know that the real provider
behaves the same way as the mock provider now one of the things you might be thinking is okay you've got this
contract that's been generated by the consumer tests how do we get that contract from the consumer side to the
provider side now we tried a few different techniques uh to solve this problem we tried using uh copy paste and
that worked about as well as you'd expect um we tried using uh Jenkins bill
artifacts and that kind of worked well until the number of builds that we had in Jenkins exceeded the maximum limit
and then they started getting deleted and and problems um so given that uh
this problem had been introduced by having too many microservices the obvious solution was to add another
micros service so um on one of the DS hack days
uh we threw together this thing that we then called the packed brok
and the pack broker is this middleman that sits between uh the consumer build and the provider build and it allows you
to exchange the contract so the consumer bill will run and publish the contract
and then the provider bill will run and pull down the latest version of that contract so this meant we um we always
the provider was always working on the latest
version now one of the things we discovered when we had been using the contract testing
um over the period of of a few months was that um you can make the same
request and depending on the state of the provider you can get a different response um so the way the contract test
the the contract had initially been written was that when the provider receives a certain request it will
return a certain response now if you only get one chance at this you don't
actually get to exercise all the code paths in your code because um sometimes you might request for resource and maybe
it doesn't exist so you get a 404 and sometimes you request the same resource and it does exist so you get a a 200 and
you you get the actual resource so this is the way a contract might look when a
provider receives a request for SL alligator slm Mar then it will return a
200 response with this Json
body we might actually get different responses for that request so what we
needed to add was a way to set up the data a way to tell the test what we
expected was going to be on that provider so that when we ran the test we got back the response that we expected
this is what we called provider States so now we can say given that
there is an alligator Mary when I run this request for an alligator Mary I get
back the alligator that I expect so with contract testing you
still do need to think about your data um but the setup for each test is much less you're not having to set up the
entire world you're just setting up the uh data for this particular
request now as time went on and we're adding
more and more data into these contracts uh they would start to fail more often
so it'd add a new field and we might say I expect this address with this street
and then the the test would fail because um the street name was a mismatch and
this actually got really really annoying until one day I I just added this what I thought was going to be a temporary hack
cuz I was like actually I don't care about what the value of this street is I just care that it's a string so I put in this hack that made
the matching instead of do exact matching do type based matching and that
actually worked so well that led us to realize that in a contract test you
actually don't really care about the exact values you really just care about the shape of the document and the types
of data in that document so what we added into the the
pack library was this ability to specify um your the consumer
requirements for a piece of dat data so maybe you'd say this is a number this is a string I need it to match this regular
expression and that made the tests much more flexible um and meant that when we
were getting failures there were much more meaningful failures there weren't failures just because a particular string was
capitalized the wrong way this means that um your test data setup is um much
less uh critical to get everything exactly right make it much easier
now in our contract testing Journey we've automated our contract testing exchange um we've set up our test data
we've made our contracts flexible it must be time for a new problem
now uh when these projects were at the start of the their life cycle the builds kept
running daily and and most of these teams are kind of working on both sides of the integration so the builds uh just
got kicked off all the time but um one day it happened that a int a change was
introduced to a contract and the provider Bill didn't get kicked off immediately and a few days later it got

like but why has this failed we didn't change anything in the provider and um that led us to a couple
of realizations the first is that when the contract does change other service needs
to know about it uh but secondly that contracts are not a good substitute for
really good communication between the teams now the first problem was pretty
easy to solve we um added in this concept of web hooks to the pack broker so that when the contract changed you
could kick off a downstream build when it comes to the uh problem of
the contracts not being a good solution for communication we uh we did nothing
because it turns out that contracts are still not a good substitute for good communication between teams uh just

driven contracts uh the contract is a a starting point for a discussion about
how this API could work it's not something that you should be using to hit each other over the head you've
still got to keep talking and keep collaborating all right that's my my
little rant over okay so the provider knows when our contract has changed and we're still
talking about our API design time for a new problem all right
um when the contract gets generated it lives on the consumer site on the
consumer CI when the contract gets verified that tends to happen in the
provider build so the provider team is very aware when that contract has failed
but the consumer team aren't necessarily because the consumer team doesn't always have uh visibility of the provider teams
build now this is a problem that we can solve with technology uh what we added into the pat
breaker was the ability to publish those verification results back to the
provider um and then the ability for the consumer to query those verification
results to see whether or not their contract had passed so the consumer
CI um publishes their contract the provider CI publishes the verification
results now we have this full circle of communication this is um a flow that
could work for you um every every organization CI is different but um
here's a a pretty standard one the consumer CI runs their tests uh they generate the contract and
publish the contract pack broker kicks off a web hook to run the provider CI
provider CI fetches that contract verifies it and then publishes the results back to the
consumer now the consum CI can then do what it needs to do with those results perhaps deploy the latest version to a
test environment or even a production environment if that's the way you like to do things now something we discovered was
that you can actually skip this second part most of the time because um it's
not actually that often that the contract changes like the number of commits that you'll make to a consumer that actually
don't involve changing the contract is actually going to be more often than when you do change the contract
so um the when you publish a contract that is exactly the same as a previous
contract you're in a sense um prever verified so you can actually go ahead
and deploy your consumer straight away without waiting for that verification to take
place um now you might be looking at this thinking that looks really
complicated and I'll be honest with you it actually takes some thought to get this all set up and integrated into your
CI but once you've done that initial effort the effort to add new
Integrations is the smallest the smallest amount of effort you're just adding a few lines to uh a consumer test
whereas your end to end tests uh might start off conceptually quite easy but as
you add more and more Integrations into that test the amount of effort to maintain and execute those tests gets
bigger and bigger now the reason for that is that when you running an end to-
end test suite and you add a new interaction and you add a test for that interaction it's unlikely that you're
going to be able to go straight to that bit of code that you want to test usually you have to set up some data and
then execute this step and this step and go to this resource and go to this page and click this and then get to the bit
that you're in interested in so you're going through code over here that you've
probably gone through tens or hundreds of times in that same test Suite so for
your new test there's more overhead than there is actual interesting test and
this overhead is the reason that endtoend test Suites bloat so
quickly a contract test allows you to test just the bit of code you're really
interested in do you want to test harder or do you want to test
smarter now you probably heard the saying if you can't deploy your services independently you don't have
microservices you have a distributed monolith do not build a distributed
monolith now one of the things we uh discovered when we were uh
publishing contracts from every consumer build and verifications from every provider build bu was that we were able

we can look at this Matrix and say well actually we know that 11 has successfully passed the test we can

12 one of the other benefits you get when you're publishing all this contract data to a centralized places you can

in a different way so one of the most common questions
I get when I talk about contract testing is but what about Swagger or open API
specification as it's called now so technically Swagger is not a
contract testing tool it's a documentation Tool uh but it can be
extended to kind of um perform a similar role you can you
can have a a mock service that's uh generated from your Swagger and and use that in your testing now this can be

parts of your API each consumer is using and that the ability to know which
parts of your API each consumer is using is the thing that makes you be able to move quickly
uh when you don't know what parts are being used and who's using them you don't want to change it so what you end
up doing is creating an entirely new version of that resource or that API and
then you have the overhead of maintaining all of those versions when you know who's using what you can say oh

using it oh it's just this team over here let's go and talk to them about changing this and then you can start to
roll out deployments so that that uh the consumer can handle either an array or
an object and it's only one and then the rest of these guys don't care about it it means you can just make these changes
really quickly you don't have to uh worry about deploying the entire world all over
again there is a really interesting approach however that might allow you to
get the benefits of both of these uh sides um atlassian has open sourced a tool
that they actually wrote internally which allows you to verify a PCT against a Swagger
document so this gives you um the benefits of really fast feedback because
you're not actually waiting for an entire uh verification uh process to run
for your contract um you're just verifying two documents against each other and even you get slightly less
confidence because you're adding in this extra layer of abstraction but for some organizations the the tradeoff of speed
against confidence is actually a a good decision uh what this relies on though
is that your Swagger document is in sync with your provider code so you either need to make sure that your Swagger is
